review_title: Objectively a toxic workplace by any standard - avoid
pros: The good people who are nice and supportive. But this isn’t really a pro its not an achievement of the organisation, you could go and stand in a field with them and its the same result. Its a failing really that the staff have to be so supportive of each other as its lacking from leadership. If only the EB and management had the same humanity as these people.
cons: After almost six years at guide dogs and now having been in a new role for a new employer I have had time to reflect on my time at Guide Dogs and want to offer an honest and constructive review of the continued failings of this organization. - This is by any standards a toxic workplace, it has been for years and years. Bullying is pretty standard at mid and senior management - my view is that it is driven from both known incompetence of individuals covering their own lack of experience. Worse it is driven by the belief that bullying is an acceptable form of behavior for staff. It is driven from top down but is visable throughout the organisation. - I have a thirty year employment history, never have i had direct reports in tears as I had at Guide Dogs - never have I had my concerns dismissed by my managers and senior leaders. -As above the mental health of staff is sadly deplorable. I had two team members experience a crises in my time at Guide Dogs, this I have never experienced in 30 years of managing staff. The support I received to deal with this was non existent and it was brushed under the carpet. I had evidence and was a witness to the verbal abuse experienced by staff from senior management that resulted in this crises. No action was taken outside of talk of resilience training for staff!. - I was witness to outrageous accusations of staff by senior management. Verbal and email abuse was common and vulnerable team members were singled out - red font type and upper caps in an an abusive email is childish and deplorable. Face to face meetings and conversations an acceptable means of communicating were not a reality in this organization sadly. - its a big organization but communication is awful. There are many big organizations who do not have these problems. The fact being that plans and strategies are not brought into, they are dropped on staff by senior leaders who then wash their hands of it. Because the plans are not fully supported it causes division in teams those trying to work hard conflict with those resisting change- creating more work, stress, frustration and disillusion. Of course HR and senior leaders do nothing, more bullying happens and things don’t change. - Nepotism is rife, I can’t count how many times incompetent staff were promoted by long term friends into senior positions. The amount of long service awards means there is an entrenched group of staff who have been employed for 20, 30+ years. This group resist change and promote from within the clique. - A common experience was huge directorate meetings where often the director would hold court over the entire directorate and single out individuals in such a humiliating way it was awful. I was shocked to see this behavior but also the style of meeting was so old fashioned and dated - completely unproductive in a modern organization. It seemed to be an exercise in bullying and fear. - Literally how long are you going to use ‘The Pandemic’ as an excuse for every failing at this organization?? Come on the whole world went through the pandemic- that means every single company and organization did too, why do you think you can keep using this as an excuse? What you do is review the impact of the pandemic and then take the relevant changes and adapt to conditions, not blunder on regardless and then when it fails say ‘oh it was the pandemic’ - are you going to keep saying this until 2033? - Honestly if you are a reasonable human being with good social skills and a experience of typical organisational processes- basically an everyday person good at their job - avoid working at this organisation, it will ruin your mental health. There are many other places to work that will not crush your soul. - Overall nice people attracted to working for a charity will be ruined by the other type of person employed, a incompetent, narcissistic bully who seems to be attracted to this organization as its one of the only places where they can get away (be rewarded even) by their toxic behaviors. (could be the norm in other charities I don’t know). If this is was a school it would be put under special measures - avoid.

pros: Rewarding role that makes a difference
cons: Senior management make questionable decisions to detriment of clients

pros: I love the team I work in and have an amazing line manager. I love working for an organisation that has a meaningful purpose.
cons: Like many organizations setting the priorities and sticking to them is a real challenge.

review_title: Organisation full of passionate and skilled people
pros: Ethical principles…dog and people wellbeing at the heart if our work.
cons: A complex business and in house supply chain. We struggle to meet the needs of all our customers.

pros:
The support you get from your colleagues on the ground. 

Pockets of incredible managers, there for the right reasons , which are few and far between.
cons:
Guide Dogs has changed beyond recognition. No longer the family it once was, now a corporate juggernaut, filled with middle management who don’t care about the end goal or weak senior management just clinging on waiting for retirement. 
Too many business schoolesque managers with 0 technical prowess, feathering their own caps with little genuine care for service users, volunteers or dog welfare, making decisions which are crippling a once fantastic organisation. 
Several accounts of bullying which are always swept under the carpet and never dealt with by weak senior managers. 
An extremely poor HR department who offer no support when dealing with sensitive issues. 
Breeding too many puppies with not enough volunteers to take them on. 
Begging for adolescent dogs from breeders they’ve shunned in the past & despite being one of the richest charities in England. 

The training of the dogs through puppy walking to training is now following a training pathway with tragically low pass rates, again being swept under the carpet or being blamed on COVID. Staff under pressure to complete training methodology being made up as they go along which is both confusing and unrealistic. Puppy walkers walking away from the role due to the red tape around the new training methods. Trainees not being prepared adequately for the job in hand by inexperienced tutors with a lack of knowledge or common sense.

“Behaviour specialists” leaving Dogs with behavioural issues for DCW to solve. 

Senior Management don’t care about the staff - everyone is very very replaceable. Guide dogs are haemorrhaging experienced staff left right and centre. And management are letting it happen.

Service users not being seen or avoided due to difficult decisions around their dogs. A ridiculously high percentage of service users that won’t get another dog due to the blanket treatment changes in criteria needed to get a dog, ruling more than capable service users out of a chance of independence again.

Preferential treatment for some service users and blatant abuse of others that have personality clashes with managers or GDMI’s. 

Poor communication.

Poor leadership.

Unmotivated co-workers. 

No acknowledgement. 

Managers rewarding certain individuals (often the more cut-throat, Machiavellian types) for doing whatever it takes to get results, regardless of the human consequences of their actions.

The direction the organisation is heading in is unsustainable. Thankfully, I’ll retire soon.

review_title: Fantastic employer - great people - great mission - great benefits
pros: Flex bens, People, Mission, Values, The positive impact on vision impaired service users, strong EDI strategy, always striving to improve both in service provision and how it can make employees work /life balance better
cons: None that I have experienced though appreciate others may see things differently. I have not had a single negative experience.

pros: Working with dogs, helping people with vision loss, developing skills and good CPD now
cons: Management can be poor, not in line with organisations vision, decisions based very much on personal opinion and feelings. Bullying culture from middle management

review_title: Great purpose and opportunity to influence
job_title: Business Architect in Warwick, West Midlands, England
pros: Flat structure with opportunity to really develop. Excellent aims as an organisation. Committed colleagues with a passion fit what we do.
cons: Charity not private sector perks. Sine budget constraints to work around.

pros:
Lovely people, I've made friends for life here. But it has been a case of bonding over shared trauma. 

Hearing the inspiring stories and working with dogs is amazing but doesn't out weigh the negatives.
cons:
The lower down you are the more you're expected to work. The longer I was there the more responsibilities trickled down. I ended up doing financial tasks that my manager had done previously, which was way out of my salary. 

There is a blame culture, everyone points the fingers. Managers divert the blame onto their employees rather than learning from mistakes. Despite many members of the team telling management that their workloads were too high and they were feeling overwhelmed nothing was done - in fact we were offered up to do more. 

When opportunities to move further up the ladder came, the right person for the job was never chosen. Resulting in a very high turnover. Despite what managers may think this is not because the employees are at the start of their careers, its because there is unjust management.

review_title: The old and new always in conflict - but all round a great place to work
pros:
Amazing charity with a long history of helping people living with sightloss.
Great family atmosphere, a lot of nice people to work with from the top down.
Fairly flexible about hybrid working, family leave, etc
cons:
Some old fashioned ways about, and not the most diverse organisation. It is trying to change though.
A lot of lifers and stick in the muds, making career progression hard. Never known so many long-service awards!

pros: Now have agile working so can work in the office and at home,
cons: Not every task is straight forward

review_title: Toxic blame culture that they won’t face up to or change
pros: Nice location - most colleagues are supportive which you will need as the organisation is run through a toxic culture of blame and bullying. The structure is hierarchical and outdated
cons: As many other reviews have stated on here this good cause is ruined by the toxic blame culture that was clear on the first day I started. Senior managers are aware of it but do nothing to change it (they don’t know how) - bullying is rife, people who do nothing all day are rewarded anyone with new ideas or challenges existing  practises get singled out and isolated and generally leave. HR and the exec board are useless in cases or bullying and harassment and are in fact part of the problem. Colleagues in tears is an almost daily occurance - the senior board are so removed from the work of the organisation and honestly don’t care - nothing changes, this is a great charity but do not take a job here. I’m not sure who wrote some positive reviews here - they must not work at the head office, are senior leaders or have just been very lucky !

pros: Use to be a good charity with a good cause but has been diluted and trying to provide too many services should stick to core service and train and provide guide dogs.
cons:
Believe all the reports about a toxic culture of blame and bullying -
Bullying is rife, starts at the top with ego fueled “Heads of Departments”
and trickles down to line managers. Mistakes made by senior mangers are quickly covered up. HR are useless if you go to them about being treated unfairly. 
Health and wellbeing is talked about a lot but definitely not practised.
The charity is wasting so much money and loosing supporters in the wake of their flippant spending and poor use of donor funds.
One example of this is the millions of pounds wasted on a rebrand no body likes.

pros:
Being able to work with really passionate and talented professionals throughout the charity who you'll learn from 
Friendly and down to earth culture 
Not content to stand still and encouraging of ideas and innovation
Feeling you can help do something positive to improve the lives of others
cons: I know some people have found the pace of change demanding at times, but others have appreciated the drive to support more service users and try new things

review_title: Don’t be fooled by the fluffy dogs!
pros: Historically a fantastic cause that still has a number of staff that stand for its core values.
cons: Unfortunately, far too many to list. All starts with CEO - obnoxious man. Guide Dogs has allowed his ego to over stretch itself and now is failing those it was established to help. Luckily, he has surrounded himself with they type of “Heads of Department” that have quickly alienated staff members and now You no longer find “long term” staff but instead quick solutions who also quickly are alienated. I am still a member of staff but am fully disillusioned!

review_title: Great cause but toxic internal politics and work environment
pros: Amazing cause, some great team mates, opportunities to get involved in fundraising events, beautiful location, dog friendly office
cons: Senior leadership team made decisions without getting opinions from those 'on the ground', culture of bullying that was acknowledged by not addressed.

pros: Very encouraging of self development, support employee well- being, genuine care about animal welfare
cons: I genuinely can’t give one!

review_title: No Longer a Charity about helping - all about numbers & CEO ego!
pros: Fantastic cause that makes a really difference for the people it serves
cons: Guide Dogs is lost. It is trying to do more then it’s core mission to the detriment of services. CEO & senior managers are so removed from frontline staff it makes the organisation hard to embrace now. New programmes that have been implemented are not sustainable, nor truely beneficial. I fear Guide Dogs will be in serious trouble in a few years unless changes are made.

pros: Good pay for an entry level job, and you get to work for a great charity.
cons: Soul draining, you begin to wonder if you're actually making things worse. Begins to feel like scamming the vulnerable. If you can't take advantage of the lonely and elderly, you won't meet your targets.

pros: Job satisfaction, great cause, friendly colleagues, loyalty to staff, particularly during these tough times
cons: Being such a large organisation, it can have a "corporate" feel to it, with the complications that can bring. Clearly some bitter, ungrateful ex employees judging by some of the reviews here.

pros: Good people and cause and dogs
cons: Pay wasn't great to be honest

pros: Fun Team, Good Cause, decent pay, Travel to different places in the south west.
cons: Job security based on your sign ups, you are on the street trying to talk to people, and convince them to give away £9 a month to sponsor the training of a puppy. People are busy with there day to day lives don't wish to stop an talk in the middle of the street, and unless you are extremely hot or charismatic, people don't take much note, no matter how friendly you are. The rules and targets are to harsh (2 sign ups a day, must be over 25) , you don't make those sales they make you feel bad and as if you are not trying hard enough, you feel micromanaged all the time, the team leader was always sat in a café somewhere just on his laptop. 9am-6pm trying to remain upbeat and smiling, approaching strangers and on your feet all day, is exhausting, no matter how hard I tried people would barely give me the time of day, most avoiding eye contact and complete ignoring you. It was exhausting and made you feel rubbish at the end if you couldn't get a sign up. After 2 weeks I was let go with no warning cos "I didn't have what they look for" Its hard work, and unrewarding.

pros:
People in most departments are decent & friendly.
It is good to know you are contributing to such a good cause.
Good work/life balance (nobody works too hard or excessive hours - some think they do, but they don't have much experience of the outside world).
cons:
Any suggestions you make are likely to get the response "but we've always done it this way".
Poor pay (but it is a charity).
If you have good skills & experience gained outside of the charity sector most people here will refuse to accept that you can add value by drawing on your background. New ideas are definitely not welcome here.
Too many people of average or low ability who really think they are high fliers.
Too much internal politics.
Inefficient processes that will never change because "we've always done it that way" (see above). 
Frustrating to see a charity wasting so much money on inefficient & wasteful activities and political correctness.
